channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Anger in London, as Killing of Unarmed Man That Sparked Riots Is Called Lawful
item.description: Angry protests occurred outside the Royal Courts of Justice, after an inquest jury decided that police officers had acted lawfully when they shot and killed an unarmed man they suspected of carrying a gun in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Lede: Rodman Serenades Kim With a Chorus of ‘Happy Birthday, Dear Marshal’
item.description: One day after he seemed to suggest that an American citizen detained in North Korea might deserve his fate, the retired basketball star Dennis Rodman sang to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, on his birthday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Dennis Rodman sings Happy Birthday to Kim Jong Un, seated above in the stands, before an exhibition basketball game in Pyongyang, North Korea on Jan. 8.

item.title: Turkish Police Purge Broadens in Corruption Inquiry
item.description: The Turkish government dismissed or reassigned police chiefs in 15 cities, a move analysts saw as part of an effort to disrupt a corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The reshuffling of law enforcement officers was indicative of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan's growing authoritarianism, analysts said.

item.title: Brazilian State in Spotlight After Gruesome Prison Video
item.description: A video showing inmates gloating over decapitation victims is drawing scrutiny to the security situation in Maranhão state, run by one of Brazil’s most powerful families.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Syria Called Eager to Be Rid of Chemical Arms
item.description: The top United Nations official in charge of overseeing the destruction of Syria’s arsenal said prospects are good to meet a mid-2014 deadline.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Nuclear Materials Report Shows Better Safekeeping
item.description: A report issued Wednesday on the security of deadly nuclear materials worldwide found steady improvement, but the United States slipped.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: The Lede: Sale of Tear Gas to Bahrain Blocked Over Concerns Raised by Rights Groups
item.description: South Korea’s government has reportedly decided to block the export of millions of tear gas shells to Bahrain, after months of pressure by human rights groups.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 8
item.description: Officials inspecting burnt coaches of a passenger train near Dahanu Road railway station in Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Railway and police officials inspecting burnt carriages of a passenger train near Dahanu Road railway station in Maharashtra. A fire on the overnight train killed at least nine people, a railway official said.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Said to Oust Qaeda-Linked Group From Its Aleppo Headquarters
item.description: The strike against the group, the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, took place amid four days of fighting that have killed more than 270 people.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Leguama Journal: Ethiopian Migrants Expelled by Saudis Remain in Limbo Back Home
item.description: Many Ethiopians who were deported after seeking work in Saudi Arabia face bleak prospects at home and put a strain on the government that had benefited from their remittances.
item.dc:creator: By BENNO MUCHLER
item.media:description: Mohammed Jemal, forefront, returning home after being deportated from Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Unemployment in Europe Stays High Amid Signs of Recovery
item.description: The jobless rate in November held at 12.1 percent in the euro zone, while retail sales improved and bond rates dropped.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: India Ink: A Growing Taste for U.S. Fast Food in India
item.description: Despite India’s reputation as a tough place to do business, foreign restaurant chains like Burger King are looking to expand, having received an enthusiastic response from a young population.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: People eating at a McDonalds outlet in New Delhi on Oct. 4, 2011.

item.title: India Asks U.S. Embassy to Cease Sales to Nondiplomats
item.description: In an escalating diplomatic spat, India accused the embassy in New Delhi of selling duty-free items to nondiplomats, a violation of local and international law.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Morsi’s Trial Is Delayed in Egypt
item.description: Officials say bad weather prevented them from flying Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president, to Cairo to face charges of inciting murder.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Virginie Nguyen Hoang/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A poster of ousted president Mohamed Morsi on the windshield of a car during clashes between his supporters and security forces in Nasr City, Cairo, on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Guardian Website Blocked in China
item.description: The British newspaper said that it did not know why access to its site had been curtailed.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Two men check their laptops in a cafe in Beijing, where access to several foreign-based news websites in blocked.

item.title: U.S. Military Helicopter Crashes on Coast of England
item.description: Police officials in Norfolk confirmed on Wednesday that the four crew members aboard a United States Air Force HH-60 Pave Hawk were killed.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: To Lower Maternal Deaths, India Urged to Reconsider Role of Midwives
item.description: Health experts and nongovernmental organizations are pushing the government to refocus its attention on community-based midwifery services as growing institutional deliveries strain the health care system.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: A mother with her child sitting on an open rickshaw, also called "van," on the main road near Patra village in West Bengal on July 8, 2013.

item.title: Deal Professor: Overhaul of Israel’s Economy Offers Lessons for United States
item.description: With a single bill, Israel is looking to revamp its economy and hopefully reduce income inequality, showing that a democracy can achieve change.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN DAVIDOFF

item.title: Saudis Back Syrian Rebels Despite Risks
item.description: The Saudis are bent on ousting Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, and his patron, Iran. But their only real means of fighting them is through a proxy war using fighters over whom they have almost no control.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: In Damascus on Tuesday, men helped a wounded girl who survived what activists said was an airstrike by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: In Thaw, British Lawmakers Visit
item.description: A delegation of British lawmakers visited Iran on Tuesday, the first such trip in years and a reflection of the slowly improving ties between the countries.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: Death of Beauty Queen in Robbery Rattles Country
item.description: Mónica Spear, a soap opera actress and former Miss Venezuela, and her ex-husband were killed by robbers after their car broke down, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Garment Workers End Strike
item.description: Tens of thousands of garment employees returned to work after a two-week pay dispute, after he authorities used deadly force to quell a strike and thwart a protest seeking a redo of a July election.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: $8.2 Million in Drugs Found Among Fruit
item.description: Supermarket workers in Berlin and Brandenburg State who were unpacking banana boxes found hundreds of pounds of cocaine, worth about $8.2 million, the police said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS COTTRELL

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Cities Ban Comic’s Shows
item.description: Mayors of several cities decided to ban the shows of Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, who is accused of insulting the memory of Holocaust victims and threatening public order with anti-Semitic gibes.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Palestinians Corner Jewish Settlers During Clash in West Bank
item.description: The confrontation in the northern West Bank was defused when the settlers, who said they had been hiking in the area, were handed over to Israeli forces.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
